headline.main: Medicines to Deter Some Cancers Are Not Taken
headline.print_headline: Drugs to Deter Some Cancers Are Not Taken
headline.sub: Experts Say Advances Are Largely Ignored;

docs.lead_paragraph: The few drugs proved to deter cancer are widely ignored, researchers say, while ineffective supplements are used.
docs.snippet: The few drugs proved to deter cancer are widely ignored, researchers say, while ineffective supplements are used.

headline.main: Drugs to Deter Some Cancers Are Not Taken

docs.lead_paragraph: Many Americans do not think twice about taking medicines to prevent heart disease and stroke. But cancer is different. Much of what Americans do in the name of warding off cancer has not been shown to matter, and some things are actually harmful. Yet the few medicines proved to deter cancer are widely ignored. Take prostate cancer, the second-most commonly diagnosed cancer in the United States, surpassed only by easily treated skin cancers. More than 192,000 cases of it will be diagnosed this year, and more than 27,000 men will die from it.
docs.snippet: Many Americans do not think twice about taking medicines to prevent heart disease and stroke. But cancer is different. Much of what Americans do in the name of warding off cancer has not been shown to matter, and some things are actually harmful. Yet...

docs.abstract: A selection of remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last week, the editors of Home Fires invited readers to send their recollections and photographs of members of the United States Armed Forces in acknowledgment of Veterans Day. Below is a selection of those remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves.
docs.snippet: A selection of remembrances submitted by friends and family of veterans, and from veterans themselves.

docs.abstract: Same as "traditional" infectious diseases, good health (like happiness) and bad (like depression) can spread through social networks.
docs.lead_paragraph: "Wash your hands regularly." "Cover your mouth when you sneeze." "Throw away your used tissues." These are some of the exhortations currently posted around London in an attempt to reduce the spread of flu. But one day, perhaps we'll have public health campaigns of a different kind. "Be jolly: it's catching." Or, "Eat less: do it for your friends."
docs.snippet: Same as "traditional" infectious diseases, good health (like happiness) and bad (like depression) can spread through social networks.
